thread.title: USA TODAY Sports Bracketology: Let's not forget about Wichita State
thread.title_full: USA TODAY Sports Bracketology: Let's not forget about Wichita State

author: USA TODAY Sports
title: USA TODAY Sports Bracketology: Let's not forget about Wichita State
text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email USA TODAY Sports Bracketology: Let's not forget about Wichita State The Shockers are 26-4 and 16-1, and just as dangerous as they've always been. Post to Facebook USA TODAY Sports Bracketology: Let's not forget about Wichita State The Shockers are 26-4 and 16-1, and just as dangerous as they've always been. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/2m7F6Te Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address.   Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs USA TODAY Sports Bracketology: Let's not forget about Wichita State Shelby Mast and Scott Gleeson, USA TODAY Sports 9:03 a.m. ET Feb. 22, 2017 CLOSE x Share Unbeaten Gonzaga (28-0) received 29 of 32 first-place votes. Villanova, Kansas, Arizona and UCLA round out the top 5. USA TODAY Sports Wichita State Shockers head coach Gregg Marshall reacts during the first half against the Michigan State Spartans in the 2016 Battle 4 Atlantis in the Imperial Arena at the Atlantis Resort. (Photo: Kevin Jairaj, USA TODAY Sports) 4 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Remember that program that stunningly went to the Final Four in 2013, almost finished undefeated in 2014, went to the Sweet 16 in 2015, and won its third consecutive Missouri Valley Conference title last season? 
Yeah, that team is still around. 
Go ahead and tell Gregg Marshall and his players that Wichita State isn't relevant or good enough anymore. They're likely counting on it. The team that is known for its signature, chip-on-your-shoulder brand of toughness is 26-4 and 16-1, which is complemented by a RPI of 40. The Shockers' overall résumé, which features only one top-50 win, puts them as the first team out in USA TODAY Sports' latest bracketology. 
In the same week they jumped to No. 25 in the USA TODAY Sports Coaches Poll , Wichita might just sneak into the field of 68 projections as a heavy contender for an at-large bid. Credit that to the fact that WSU keeps winning as well as a relatively weak bubble with fringe teams (ahem, Indiana) continually losing. 
Should we be surprised? Maybe, considering the emergence of Illinois State — another bubble team with a better RPI (33) but uglier, résumé-staining losses. Midway through the season, the Redbirds took it to the Shockers in a 76-62 decision, as if to say the Valley was no longer theirs. Marshall and Co. weren't having it. Their next meeting against an injury-prone Illinois State was a statement win if there is such a thing. They clobbered the Redbirds by 41 points in Wichita. And that trend has continued here in February as March nears. They obliterated Northern Iowa by 29 points this past weekend and destroyed Evansville by 26 on Tuesday night. On their 10-game winning streak, only one of those wins wasn't decided by double figures. Although the selection committee won't necessarily use this data, it's kind of impossible to ignore when comparing to a power conference team six games below .500. 
"Last year we weren't supposed to be in, then we have Arizona down by 25," Marshall told reporters last week . "They were a No. 6 seed. You gotta ask Sean Miller and teams that have played us. How good are they? Do you want to see them in your bracket?" 
The departure of All-Americans Fred VanVleet and Ron Baker seemed to leave the cupboard bare for 2016-17. But in reality, WSU's success has never been about individual players. In fact, the Shockers' team that went to the Final Four was hardly Marshall's best team. It was just the one no one saw coming. 
► No. 1 seeds: Villanova, Kansas, Gonzaga, North Carolina 
► Last four in: Syracuse, Tennessee, TCU, Kansas State 
► First four out: Wichita State, Clemson, Vanderbilt, Illinois 
► Others considered for at-large bids (in no particular order): Georgetown, Wake Forest, Providence, Georgia Tech, Alabama, Pittsburgh, Indiana 
► On life support: Rhode Island, Houston, Ohio State, Georgia, Ole Miss, Penn State. 
► No longer considered: UConn, Texas Tech, Texas, Texas Arlington, Charleston, New Mexico, Boise State, LaSalle, Davidson, Chattanooga, Saint Bonaventure, Saint Joseph's, BYU, Oklahoma, Charleston, Nebraska, Temple, North Carolina State, Stanford, Nevada, Texas A&M, Memphis, Utah, Iowa, Auburn 
Moving in: Kansas State 
Moving out: Clemson 
► Multi-bid conferences: ACC (10), Big Ten (7), Big 12 (6), Big East (6), Pac-12 (5), SEC (5), A-10 (2), AAC (2), WCC (2). Conference Leaders 
► Or highest RPI from projected one-bid conferences - (23 total): Vermont (America East), Florida Gulf Coast (Atlantic Sun), North Dakota (Big Sky), UNC-Asheville (Big South), UC Irvine (Big West), UNC-Wilmington (CAA), Middle Tennessee State (Conference USA), Valparaiso (Horizon), Yale (Ivy League), Monmouth (MAAC), Akron (MAC), N.C. Central (MEAC), Illinois State (Missouri Valley), Boise State (Mountain West), Mount Saint Mary's (Northeast), Belmont (Ohio Valley), Bucknell (Patriot), Furman (Southern), New Orleans (Southland), Texas Southern (SWAC), North Dakota State (Summit), Texas-Arlington (Sun Belt), New Mexico State (WAC). 
Banned from participating: Hawaii, Southern Mississippi, Alcorn State, Savannah State, Northern Colorado Transition Schools, ineligible for the tourney: Abilene Christian (Southland), Grand Canyon (WAC), Incarnate Word (Southland), Massachusetts-Lowell (American East) 
*** 
Note: All RPI and statistical data is used from WarrenNolan.com . 
About our bracketologist: Shelby Mast has been projecting the field since 2005 and has finished as one of the top 5 national bracketologists for his website, Bracket W.A.G. He’s predicted for The Indianapolis Star, collegeinsider.com and is an inaugural member of the Super 10 Selection Committee. Follow him on Twitter @BracketWag . 
NCAA TOURNAMENT BUBBLE TEAMS
